author: @hensteeth
text: It's great to hear the perspective of someone in my generation. I lived in the South, and don't think I ever heard the name of Marx, but little things around me gave me questions to think about. Science fiction opened my eyes to the possibilities of other worlds. It was a long journey before I finally found Marxism.

replies.author: @zachflame123
replies.text: @hensteeth I love that story. Have you read H.G. Wells "New Worlds for Old"?

replies.author: @hensteeth
@voodustyle
replies.text: I'm also from the South and had never heard of Marx until college but being African-American and in our communities is a hell of a precondition for being skeptical of the systems that run our lives. Manga/comics, film, and video games did for me what reading sci-fi did for you. You start asking questions and rejecting the idea that this world is immutable.

author: @tylerb.-hq7fq
text: Great program! I've heard Catharine speak several times. She's awesome. I worked for SEIU Local 925 in Washington State for 20 years and recently retired. It is a Union of education workers ran by women and is 65-70% women membership. We fought for childcare workers who did state subsidized care for poor and working-class families and transformed these workers' wages and benefits. There is still work to be done but great strides have been made. I was often the only male in a room full of strong, powerful women of the working class. You are right on, we talked about wages, benefits, retirement, affordable health care. But I will say that even with this working class, Marxist work I still had to deal with the Democratic Party, the Unions are wedded to them, and all the Identify politics. But I think we are on the verge of a shift away from this to more working-class analysis and action. Thanks for your work. Tyler

replies.author: @eemoogee160
replies.text: Do you sense that more union members are sufficiently fed up with the duopoly?

replies.author: @tylerb.-hq7fq
replies.text: yes, there was huge rank and file union member support for Bernie in 2016 and he got the endorsement of the union in 2020, in the primary.

author: @patrickholt2270
text: Overcoming injustice by raising the consciousness of one person at a time is a religious project.  You can describe Christianity and Buddhism in exactly that way, and I have as a Christian from time to time.  It's not a political strategy at all, except indirectly in that the rehabilitation and healing of the person in a Christian community produces organic leaders and resilience to take into political struggle.   It does absolutely risk deviating into escapism and fantasy struggle in place of real world struggle against injustice.

author: @brodie_johnson
text: I‚Äôm new to Catherine (and Marxist theory lol), so is it accurate that her stance on trans rights/pronouns is that trans people should exist and be protected, but demanding working class people to conform to the use of pronouns is wrong when their material needs are entirely ignored? That it‚Äôs a way of turning liberals against the working class?

replies.author: @eemoogee160
replies.text: What does it mean to demand conformity to pronoun usage?

replies.author: @wyrmsw
replies.text: I believe (and this is only drawn from this) that she is trying to say that trans people should exist and be protected, but often they are weaponized in order to draw attention from reasonable healthcare etc in order to distract from real issues to working class people. I think she's trying to ask, "Is (pronouns) really the issue that we need to be confronting, rather than maternity leave, etc."

replies.author: @eemoogee160
replies.text: @wyrmsw¬† no pronouns are respected until all pronouns are respected

replies.author: @jasondelvaux3036
replies.text: @eemoogee160 Pronouns don't matter when you don't eat. People can handle such issues like that on their own, one on one. If someone wants me to call them one thing or another, they can ask me that and I'll do my best to honor them. But you cannot legislate speech or human behavior. And, again, if someone's major issue is pronouns when we ALL have critical issues around war, healthcare, the environment, education, and corporate totalitarianism, then lucky them. Clearly they don't have any real problems in their life.

replies.author: @Barklord
replies.text: My view is that the Right Wing has been redirecting the discontent of the working-class by focusing on culture war issues that avoid the real problem. Most people really don't feel threatened by transgender folks but they do feel threatened by job insecurity, rent, lack of health care, etc. Class politics can eliminate the source of anger that gets misdirected into scapegoating of all kinds.

replies.author: @eemoogee160
replies.text: @Barklord¬† Democrats and even establishment "leftist" institutions also use identity politics to divide workers and distract them from uniting in struggle.

author: @justinm7285

author: @blaisekroma9689
text:
This is just a collection of slogans connected with "do good things for the people" sentimentalism. She says "we" i.e the PMC should be focussing more on the working class instead of identity but that is ipso facto an articulation of the same class-collaborationist, reformist, social fascist identity politics she claims to be rejecting. The only reason the PMC would collaborate with the people they are oppressing, would be to secure their own reproduction via a mass identity that integrating some of the oppressed into the lower ranks of the exploiters. Which, by definition, would exclude the vast majority of the human race, and reject violent anti-parliamentary revolution as the primary strategic goal. Besides all of that, the conditions for a renewed class collaborationist capitalism are rotting in the trash heap of 20th century leftism. It's sad and pathetic that this is the horizon of anti-establishment "leftism" in 2024.

An internationally organized working class would, by definition, focus on its collective needs and the discussion of race/lgbt issues which is currently hegemonised by identity politics would also become emancipatory within that movement. The fundamental question then is why _that_ hasn't happened yet and how it might happen in the future... instead of why liberal PMCs aren't being nice to the "working class". And that is exactly what anti-woke socialism amounts to because real working class demands have to come out of a real working class movement and its party. They can never be conjured up by self-critical and apologetic members of the parasitic classes interested in doing good things for the people.

replies.author: @ugh_lily
replies.text: yes! i feel so trepidatious when listening to critiques of the ‚Äúwoke left‚Äù because i worry it will end up in the same pitfall. i despise that when one calls out the dems for example for only engaging in performative activism and support for people in communities that are within and also distinct from just working class, that they also forget that all these people, who the pmcs have tokenized, are actually all working class people and are exploited, disenfranchised and so on on the basis of their identity within the working class! why do we hate intersectionality so much? i promise it‚Äôs okay for us to take issues of race and queerness seriously within the labor movement

author: @dfinma
text: 35:13 My comment will only be misinterpreted but here goes -- why should I pay for someone else's parental leave? Once upon a time, not that long ago, a single income could raise a family so parental leave wasn't necessary. The real problem lies with our governmental-economic system which has made it necessary for both parents to work. But back to the point -- I don't have kids so I never have and never will get parental leave so why should I pay for others'?

author: @Birdeye75
text:
I like everything i hear here and i was looking for the subject, specifically the professional class protecting large monied interests and keeping the working class under control 
I found her
There wasn't much else to be found 
This subject is almost taboo and yet I believe the only way to solve all the issues that persist
Activism for this or that might not be enough if those security guards are allowed to work almost under the radar
Here's my only criticism 
The first place i found her was on Jimmy Dore's show. A leftist turned right-wing grifter whom i once admired greatly. In fact he still follows me on social media 
She doesn't speak harshly at all when it comes to the right
I get it. I too believe the Democrats enabled more than i have the time to get into
But as a serious person I can't ignore that and i don't see how you can. In fact for me I would need to consciously ignore the sins on the other side. Because it's not easy to do. My hatred of neoliberalism is immense yet I have eyes and ears
If we're going to take down a system we can't expect it to crumble by leaving one load bearing post untouched

author: @MariusTrotter-sw1ml
text: Good discussion. A lot of leftists who claim to be critical of identity politics continue to cling to aspects of it because they insist there is some 'good', truly revolutionary form of idpol as opposed to the 'bad' kind that is pushed by the Democrats and corporations. The reality is, the more you study the origins and genealogy of queer theory, contemporary feminism and Critical Race Theory, the more you realize it was a bourgeois op from the get go. It was anti working class from early onwards, from the 1960's at least. Moreover, the working class does not care that your version of identity politics has some rhetoric about socialism and communism sprinkled in, its still essentially the same as what the Democrats are pushing. If it looks like a duck, sounds like a talk, walks like a duck, its a duck. This election shows this discourse and rhetoric is utterly toxic to the working class beyond a reasonable doubt.

author: @ugh_lily
text: while i agree with catherine on the fact that trans people (myself being a working class blue collar one) carry disdain for the democrats for using us as a talking point, i do think that lacks the real world understanding that my life and existence is being threatened by those in power and by many who support them. i do not want my existence to be debated, but what difference is there from the discussions on gay marriage and trans women being allowed in restrooms? i agree with her when she talks about not needing to worry about everyone‚Äôs signifiers and in-depth undertaking and simply needing respect - but i think that she deemphasizes the issue at hand here when i am painted by people in the highest offices in this country as a man who wants to further control over and take advantage of women and children. i really enjoy her work and i agree so much about how feminism has been coopted (the battle of the sexes is so obviously trying to pit working people against one another) but i think downplaying the rights of trans people missed the mark for it just being an elite and capitalist issue in a sense. while i think the dems may have exacerbated the hatred in the mainstream for trans people, i believe the right would‚Äôve taken issue with it similarly to how they have now just by virtue that we take up more visible space in the kodern day. maybe im misunderstanding her though!

author: @nelsfrye8570
text: I was very much on board with everything intellectually until we got to the moment where she said that Chinese women have the month of ÂùêÊúàÂ≠ê covered. Going to a public hospital is a nightmare except for in the case of a very rare set of hospitals typically reserved for the elite or people who can pay top dollar. There are private hospitals, but the insurance for those is not a heck of a lot cheaper than it is here in the US since these are typical typically foreign providers and foreign owned hospitals. In the public hospitals, where waiting in long lines is common, it‚Äôs common even to have a Caesarian  pushed on the woman to get her through the hospital quick quicker. The Chinese medical system is complicated and I‚Äôm not gonna try to claim that it‚Äôs drastically worse than the one here because it has some merits, and the one here is so bad, But certainly not one of those areas where the PRC has excelled. Those would be more like fast rail.

author: @amelliangames7365
text: I'm confused by her argument. Im not sure who exactly she is attacking. "The gentrification of trauma." Maybe it was women getting together to broaden the scope of PTSD. Is that bad? I'm a counselor and work with trauma and yes, people can and are traumatized by events other than war and deserve care as well. It affects the nervous system and can lead to anxiety, panic attacks, avoidance behaviors, etc. I'm not sure what her point is, it comes across as 'oh look at these dumb feminists who advocated for sexual abuse survivors instead of leading the revolution.'

replies.author: @HashFace253
replies.text: @amelliangames7365 I think she goes into some of her thoughts around 23 is minutes then critique 26:20 and on for a bit.

replies.author: @thewordygecko
replies.text: I think she is talking about individualisation being promoted over class and the collective. I don't believe she's being unfairly critical here as she does say that treating women who have survived sexual abuse etc as trauma in the same way that men who have PTSD from war is a good thing. She's not denigrating traumatised women or other people but rather criticising the way in which their suffering has been gentrified rather than examined and treated within a lens of class consciousness where they can get more support from everyone around them and not be atomised.

author: @expedition346
text:
i dont understand;  how else would women, excluded from industrial/pooled labor, supposed to gain class consciousness?  weren't they confined within the domestic sphere?  so therefore it wouldn't be so much "deflecting and suppressing the kinds of solidarity that were necessary to create real political change" [30:15] as trailblazing a new approach for increasing consciousness?  what other way of organizing could women do, other than consciousness-raising groups?

and i dont understand arguments about how feminism is tearing working class solidarity apart (apart from the post-second wave nonsense);  i think it's actually men who are tearing solidarity apart, by being assholes (to put it lightly).  one side abuses the other, the other side recognizes the abuse, and people expect the other side to be fine with it?  i think that expectation is the idealist position here.

personally, i dont see patriarchy dying down on its own anytime soon, so the answer is for women to either grin and bear it, or separate (if anyone has other ideas, pls let me know).  And in separation, however unfeasible it may be, women could create bases of dual power.
first time stumbling onto this channel and to Liu; do they discuss Dworkin at all?  if so could anyone point me toward such discussion..

to me i just feel like all this stems from idealism having never really been eradicated.  psychoanalysis, deleuze-guattari, post-modernism, etc.

honestly such a refreshing voice for the online left.  and she pronounces "ideology" like me (the correct pronunciation btw)!

replies.author: @blaisekroma9689
replies.text:
"what other way of organizing could women do, other than consciousness-raising groups?"

Consciousness-raising by whom and for what? This is the exact same idealism at the centre of Liu's PMC thesis, but applied to "women" instead of "working class". Obviously you're not talking about all women, but middle-class and rich and mostly white women. And Liu is obviously not talking about the working class, but lower-middle-class and mostly white Americans. There is no reason to believe any group will advance human liberation because a petty-bourgeois academic abstractly identifies a contradiction between their identity and a specific form of the rule of capital.

"i think it's actually men who are tearing solidarity apart, by being assholes (to put it lightly)."

Men were assholes when there was a working class movement that included women. The billions of men in the third world whose deprivation and misery fuels your middle-class life (regardless of how "guilty" you feel about that) are also assholes. Are "hard-working Americans" of all genders refusing to act (as opposed to posture) in solidarity with the third world because they are assholes? Or is it because they have no objective reason to do so, which is largely if not totally unrelated to whether they are nice or assholes?

All revolutions inherited the contradictions of the very same social order they sought to abolish, and which led to more revolution or reform. Women's emancipation as labour emerged out of the broader working class movement while being antagonistic to it. Nonetheless, making revolution is the only way to resolve contradictions, and no one has the power to decide how or why it is made. The question is what one does when the revolution happens, not how one would like it to happen. The essence of reformism/social fascism is to idealistically derive the former from the latter. Because _how contradictions should be mediated_ is always nothing more than the self-criticism of capital and therefore an articulation of its structural logic. Hope you didn't take offense where none was intended, and all the best.

replies.author: @felixlevert5468
replies.text:
Say you don't understand how feminism is ruining working class cohesion, proceed to call men assholes in the same sentence. 

Ok dude ü§°

author: @amelliangames7365
text:
So is Catherine anti-trans? She apparently acknowledges the good gay marriage amd acceptance has done, but then speaks out against highlighting trans rights. And then you mock pronouns. I agree to support trans people you want universal healthcare, obviously. But trans people are being killed and targeted, denied healthcare, arrested for using bathrooms, harassed at schools, and banned from sports.

The answer isnt to mock trans people and say we dont matter and justify attacking us by saying the dems are co-opting our struggle. Ofc the dems are capitalists and arent going to help us. But you attacking us is just fueling the rhetoric that the right uses to justify taking away our rights and using violence. My trans friends cant get healthcare right now bc of the right attacking us. Why cant you say yes trans rights AND we can get trans rights through medicare for all. But you spend ten minutes attacking us and blaming us for the dems co-opting us.

replies.author: @Lawns-Are-Fun
replies.text:
I had a whole long answer but honestly it‚Äôs like smacking my head against a wall. This is really the only thing people like you care about. And then you say ‚ÄúI care about X issue too‚Äù but the only one you‚Äôre in every comment section screeching about is this. Every single time. It‚Äôs you‚Äôre only
Issue. Never see these commenters asking stop funding Ukraine or IzRe3l; never see it for universal healthcare when we have commodified healthcare hell; or to give public housing‚Äîjust the same social issue that impacts like .01% of people in this country‚Ä¶.great

replies.author: @ollieopolis
replies.text:
@amelliangames7365 my understanding is that she is debating if pronouns is the hill to die on, when there are more materially relevant aspects to push for. That expecting working class cis people to start using pronouns alienates us from them rather than sharing our need for universal health care and what not. Pronouns are almost a diversion because they seem like an easy ask but distract from the material needs of trans people. 

I could be wrong though. I'm also trans and find this challenging to pass because I'm like I need people to know my pronouns in the same way they need to know my name.

author: @denizen7even

Responding that it‚Äôs part of the language is completely irrelevant.

replies.author: @Lawns-Are-Fun
replies.text: @denizen7evenYeah that makes sense and that‚Äôs what I‚Äôm trying to convey‚ÄîI do the same thing‚Äîfor instance, if someone tells me their ‚Äúpartner‚Äù or ‚Äúsignificant other‚Äù did X or Y, and I have no information on whether that person is a man or a woman, and I don‚Äôt want assume (because I think that can be kind of rude), I will say ‚Äúoh wow what did *they* do?‚Äù But, again, I think this comes down to just trying to be polite and  respectful. But telling people they must use they for me is out the question and crazy. And I think assuming people are evil because they made some minor mistake assuming a pronoun is kind of weird too.

Literally Catherine said in the first like 30 minutes that she doesn‚Äôt like Trump. 
   Every MAGA communist in the forefront doesn‚Äôt support Trump, but they support the MAGA people because many of them have seeds for communist views even though those folks have been taught to that ‚Äúcommunism is when capitalism or imperialism‚Äù and that ‚Äú‚Äòcommunism‚Äô (capitalism- imperialism) is bad‚Äù.
